column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Teach Disabled People to Take Care of a Pet
#Text=Pets make great friends for anyone , especially people who have difficulty relating to others .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Considering Whether to Get a Pet
#Text=Not all people with disabilities are able to care for pets .
#Text=Carefully consider the person and their situation when making a decision about whether to buy a pet , and what type of pet to buy .
#Text=Notice how the person interacts with other animals .
#Text=If they are afraid of animals , then a pet is probably not a good idea .
#Text=If they respond positively to animals , and know how to be gentle , then a pet might be a good idea .
#Text=Getting over a fear of animals takes time and care .
#Text=A pet should only be gotten once the person is pretty comfortable around animals .
#Text=Extremely fearful people might become afraid of a pet if they have a bad experience .
#Text=Consider how rough or gentle a disabled child is .
#Text=A child that breaks toys or hits others is not ready for a pet .
#Text=They may upset the pet and get scratched or bitten .
#Text=Some disabled children are very tough .
#Text=Because hitting does n't hurt them , they do n't realize that it hurts others .
#Text=They need someone to explain this to them , and to set rules .
#Text=Consider whether the disabled person understands personal space .
#Text=If they do n't , they may upset the pet , and get bitten/scratched .
#Text=The disabled person should be able to set boundaries ( and have others listen to those boundaries ) , and should know how to respect others ' boundaries .
#Text=Does the disabled person respect other people 's boundaries ?
#Text=If so , they will probably respect a pet 's boundaries .
#Text=Do other people routinely violate the disabled person 's boundaries ( including personal space ) ?
#Text=If so , the disabled person will think it 's okay to violate boundaries .
#Text=Is the person in compliance therapy ?
#Text=If so , they may not realize that people and animals are allowed to set boundaries , much less that these boundaries need to be honored .
#Text=Evaluate the person 's self-care abilities .
#Text=If they struggle to take care of themselves , then they may not be able to handle a pet .
#Text=Do n't put extra responsibilities on an overtaxed person .
#Text=Alternatively , if they are handling things well , and they say they could handle a pet , then they are probably ready .
#Text=Consider how much care other household members can contribute .
#Text=For example , if a disabled girl 's dad is willing to clean up after it , her brother will feed it , and her sister will walk it , then she may not need to be responsible for it .
#Text=Talk to them , and see how much care they might think they would be able to handle .
#Text=Teaching the Disabled Person
#Text=Talk about personal space and pets .
#Text=Just like people , pets have personal space and do n't always want to play or be petted .
#Text=Encourage the person to pay attention to the pet 's body language , and to leave the pet alone if it wants to be alone .
#Text=Encourage the person to call a pet by holding out their hand and/or making kissy sounds .
#Text=Explain that if the pet wants to come , it will come .
#Text=Otherwise , it wants alone time , so let it be .
#Text=Explain how to avoid scaring a pet .
#Text=Pets have slightly different social norms than people do , so it 's important that all household members learn how to interact appropriately with a pet .
#Text=Be gentle .
#Text=Never sneak up on a pet .
#Text=Use your indoor voice .
#Text=Do n't shout or scream at a pet .
#Text=Leave a sleeping pet alone .
#Text=Do n't chase a pet .
#Text=If a pet walks or runs away and wants to be alone , do n't pester it .
#Text=Do n't tease or take away a toy the pet is playing with .
#Text=Leave the pet alone when it is eating .
#Text=Explain how to tell if a pet wants to be alone .
#Text=Different animals
#Text=Encourage the person to help with feeding/walking the pet .
#Text=Teach them how to fill the pet 's bowl and store the food .
#Text=If teaching about dogs , especially show them to never let a dog off of the leash , unless in a secured area .
#Text=Walking and feeding pets is an important bonding experience .
#Text=Teach the person how to tell if a pet is angry .
#Text=Tell them that growling/hissing are signs of anger , and to slowly walk away .
#Text=Also , show the person not to touch the food bowl while they 're eating , or take a toy away .
#Text=Tell them to never pull a pets tail .
#Text=Teach the person how to pet an animal gently .
#Text=Show them how to rub a dog 's belly , or pet a cat 's ears .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Have patience .
#Text=Do n't force the person to help if they 're afraid/upset .
#Text=Have the disabled person give treats to the new pet .
#Text=This will help the pet like them .
